That is a false fact about melatonin.  It's based on whatever queue your body gets used to for sleep.  Darkness during nighttime and sunlight just happens to be the most common thing between all humans (and obviously all animals) which is why that's what it is most often linked to.  In reality, this can be linked to pretty much anything.  If you go to sleep CONSISTENTLY really late where let's say you only get 1 hour of sleep when it's dark and for the rest of the time the sun is already up, this wouldn't change your melatonin levels.  The reason it's so often a problem in so many tests is because they switch people over to sleeping on a night shift, people who take night shift jobs have other things to manage in their life and the general patterns of the people around them like family don't allow them to sleep normally, and in general there tends to be a conflict with the active times of most other people based in society.  That first tip would in many cases be accurate but it's based on false science and a few assumptions.  It's funny how you don't see the irony in having brought up that alarm clock.

Find the light - expose your body to light to reduce melatonin production. Sunlight, or a brightly lit home.
Splash cold water - a shock of cold water makes you wakeful and alert, and reduces fatigue
Hydrate - normal dehydration through sweat or urination makes you more fatigued. Rehydrate quickly in the morning.
Eat a healthy breakfast - eating helps you feel more alert first thing in the morning. Beware excess fats that can make you eat more later, or simple sugars that cause an early energy crash. Complex carbs like oatmeal is perfect.
Drink orange juice - for the flavonoids, which fight cognitive decline due to aging or Alzheimer's.
Be active - increased blood flow increases oxygen to the brain, improving mental performance and function of the hippocampus, which controld learning and memory (among other things).
Listen to music - it increases activity in the brain associated with movement and emotional centers, and may help release dopamine which makes you feel good.
